infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo

    public interface TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate
extends ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

    Interface for implementations of the transfer entropy (TE), which may be applied to multivariate continuous time-series data. That is, it is applied to double[][] data, indexed by time then by variable number. See Schreiber below for the definition of transfer entropy, Lizier et al. (2011) for the extension to multivariate source and destination, and and Lizier et al. (2008) for the definition of local transfer entropy. Specifically, this class implements the pairwise or apparent transfer entropy; i.e. we compute the transfer that appears to come from a single source variable, without examining any other potential sources (see Lizier et al, PRE, 2008).

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using ChannelCalculatorCommon.setProperty(String, String) which at this level includes destination history embedding length but not delays or source embedding (TODO pull this up from TeMultivariateViaCondMi)
    3. Initialise the calculator using ChannelCalculatorCommon.initialise() or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.initialise(int, int) or initialise(int, int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][], boolean[], boolean[]) or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][], boolean[][], boolean[][]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], int, int), then
        3. ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average TE: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local TE values for these samples: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local TE values for a specific set of samples: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][])
      • the distribution of MI values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int) or ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • J.T. Lizier, J. Heinzle, A. Horstmann, J.-D. Haynes, M. Prokopenko, "Multivariate information-theoretic measures reveal directed information structure and task relevant changes in fMRI connectivity", Journal of Computational Neuroscience, vol. 30, pp. 85-107, 2011.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier, email, www

    • Field Detail

      • K_PROP_NAME

        static final java.lang.String K_PROP_NAME
        Property name to specify the history length k. For calculators which implement both this and TransferEntropyCalculator, they will need to explicitly disambiguate between K_PROP_NAME and TransferEntropyCalculator.K_PROP_NAME
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • initialise

        void initialise(int k,
              int sourceDimensions,
              int destDimensions)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for re-use with new observations. History length k, source and destination dimensions are specified here; all other parameters remain unchanged.
        Parameters:
        k - destination history embedding length to be considered.
        sourceDimensions - number of joint variables in the source
        destDimensions - number of joint variables in the destination
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
